children: A 27-year-old woman is evaluated for contraceptive counseling. She is nulliparous. Medical history is significant for migraine with aura. She is sexually active and has a history of multiple male partners. She is a nonsmoker. She takes no medications.
Which of the following is the most appropriate contraceptive option for this patient?

Contraindications to estrogen-containing contraceptives include migraine with aura, history of breast cancer, venous thromboembolic disease, uncontrolled hypertension, or smoking more than 15 cigarettes a day for women older than 35 years.

Non-estrogen hormonal contraception options are levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine devices (IUDs), subdermal progestin implant, depot medroxyprogesterone acetate injection, and progesterone-only oral contraceptive pills; a copper IUD is a nonhormonal option.
The most appropriate contraceptive option for this patient is the levonorgestrel-releasing intrauterine device (IUD) (

). This patient has a history of migraine with aura, which is a contraindication to estrogen owing to increased risk for stroke. Women with contraindications to estrogen should be prescribed either a progesterone-only or a nonhormonal contraceptive option. For this patient, progesterone-only contraceptive options include the levonorgestrel-releasing IUD, subdermal progestin implant, depot medroxyprogesterone acetate injection, or progesterone-only oral contraceptive pill. A nonhormonal contraceptive option is the copper IUD. The patient's history of multiple sexual male partners and being nulliparous are not a contraindication to IUD use. IUDs are well tolerated. Changes in menstrual bleeding patterns are the most common adverse effect. Complications include expulsion (3%-6% in the first year) and uterine perforation (approximately 0.1% of insertions). Contraindications to IUD placement include pregnancy; anatomic uterine abnormalities with distortion of the uterine cavity; and acute untreated pelvic infection. Risk for pelvic infection with IUD placement is low, and prophylactic antibiotics are not recommended during the procedure.
Estrogen-containing contraception, including the combined hormonal (estrogen-progesterone) contraceptive pill (

), is contraindicated in patients with a history of migraine with aura, such as this patient. Other contraindications to estrogen-containing contraception include a history of breast cancer, venous thromboembolic disease, uncontrolled hypertension, and smoking more than 15 cigarettes a day for women older than 35 years.

) is a flexible device approximately 5 cm in diameter and 4 mm thick that is inserted vaginally by the patient and worn for 3 weeks and then removed and discarded. A new vaginal ring is inserted 1 week later. The vaginal ring is as effective as combined oral contraceptive pills in preventing pregnancy. The combined hormonal (estrogen-progesterone) vaginal ring is not an appropriate option because estrogen is contraindicated in this patient.
Although barrier contraceptive methods, such as male condoms (
), are safe for women who cannot take estrogen and can provide protection from sexually transmitted infections, when used alone they are considered one of the least effective forms of contraception.

objective.__html: Provide contraceptive care for a patient with migraine with aura.
